page.title: 02HOUSING
page.content: Bewdley is described as a good example of a{Georgian}town.One of the oldest buildings in the town is the Bailiff's House built in 1610.It is now a restaurant,with natural coloured oak framework renovated in 1969.In the two main streets are Georgian houses.One example is the Manor House built in 1723.Some still have the false painted windows,a reminder of the{window tax.} The two main{council estates}are Bark Hill and Queensway built in the 1930's.Later in the 1950's two private housing estates were built on the site of many cherry orchards.So some of the roads are named after types of cherries.The latest houses in Bewdley are of French design.Not many houses are built nowadays because of unemployment in the area.
